events.description: A private SSH key is exposed in the application repository or codebase.
Ensure the SSH private key file is located in a secure location. Ideally SSH private keys should be stored in a local folder, a hardware wallet, or a key vault.

properties.longDescription: A private SSH key is exposed in the application repository or codebase.

events.description: The docker service container is configured to permit writing to the root filesystem. This makes some security attack vectors such as privilege escalation, denial-of-service or authorization bypass possible since the container instance's filesystem can be tampered with.
Explicitly set the `read-only` attribute of the service to `true` to create a service container with a read-only filesystem.

properties.longDescription: The docker service container is configured to permit writing to the root filesystem. This makes some security attack vectors such as privilege escalation, denial-of-service or authorization bypass possible since the container instance's filesystem can be tampered with.

events.description: The docker service container is configured to permit writing to the root filesystem. This makes some security attack vectors such as privilege escalation, denial-of-service or authorization bypass possible since the container instance's filesystem can be tampered with.
Explicitly set the `read-only` attribute of the service to `true` to create a service container with a read-only filesystem.

properties.longDescription: The docker service container is configured to permit writing to the root filesystem. This makes some security attack vectors such as privilege escalation, denial-of-service or authorization bypass possible since the container instance's filesystem can be tampered with.

events.description: The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.
Disable container privilege escalation by explicitly setting `no-new-privileges` to `true`.

properties.longDescription: The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.

events.description: The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.
Disable container privilege escalation by explicitly setting `no-new-privileges` to `true`.

properties.longDescription: The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.

events.description: The Docker container requests the `NET_RAW` capability, either explicitly or by default, granting access to the host's network interfaces.
Explicitly remove the `NET_RAW` capability by adding either `NET_RAW` or `ALL` to the `cap_drop` list and avoiding the `NET_RAW` capability in the `cap_add` list.

properties.longDescription: The Docker container requests the `NET_RAW` capability, either explicitly or by default, granting access to the host's network interfaces.
properties.type: Container requests ability to craft raw network packets

events.description: The Docker container requests the `NET_RAW` capability, either explicitly or by default, granting access to the host's network interfaces.
Explicitly remove the `NET_RAW` capability by adding either `NET_RAW` or `ALL` to the `cap_drop` list and avoiding the `NET_RAW` capability in the `cap_add` list.

properties.longDescription: The Docker container requests the `NET_RAW` capability, either explicitly or by default, granting access to the host's network interfaces.
properties.type: Container requests ability to craft raw network packets

events.description: The Docker container is not configured to drop all default capabilities and then add only required one. Thus the container may be granted excessive privileges which violate the least privilege principle.
Remove all the default capabilities from the list of capabilities by setting the `cap_drop` value to `ALL` and then add only specific capabilities needed by a container.

properties.longDescription: The Docker container is not configured to drop all default capabilities and then add only required one. Thus the container may be granted excessive privileges which violate the least privilege principle.

events.description: The Docker container is not configured to drop all default capabilities and then add only required one. Thus the container may be granted excessive privileges which violate the least privilege principle.
Remove all the default capabilities from the list of capabilities by setting the `cap_drop` value to `ALL` and then add only specific capabilities needed by a container.

properties.longDescription: The Docker container is not configured to drop all default capabilities and then add only required one. Thus the container may be granted excessive privileges which violate the least privilege principle.

events.description: The `sandbox` attribute of an `iframe` is not set in HTML. This iframe loads content from a third-party site. If the JavaScript in that iframe is malicious or was compromised, an attacker can break out of the iframe, access the DOM of the main page, and mount a clickjacking or a phishing attack.

Enable all restrictions by setting the `sandbox` attribute of the `iframe` to an empty value, or just allow necessary capabilities by setting the `sandbox` attribute with specific value(`allow-forms`, `allow-modals`, `allow-scripts`, etc.). Avoid setting both `allow-scripts` and `allow-same-origin` at the same time as they are a vulnerable attributes combination.

issues.extra: missing_iframe_sandbox_html -- views/tutorial/ssrf.html -- ##Σ-markup - div - div - div - div - iframe

properties.longDescription: The `sandbox` attribute of an `iframe` is not set in HTML. This iframe loads content from a third-party site. If the JavaScript in that iframe is malicious or was compromised, an attacker can break out of the iframe, access the DOM of the main page, and mount a clickjacking or a phishing attack.

events.description:
The application uses an anchor tag whose `target` attribute is set to `_blank`, but the `rel` attribute is not set with the `noopener` value. The page opened from that target link may have the access to the `location` object of the original page through `window.opener.location`. A malicious page associated with this link will be able to navigate the original page to an arbitrary site, such as a phishing site, and thus, execute a reverse tabnabbing attack.
Note that most contemporary browsers add the `noopener` value to the `rel` automatically by default. Thus, only users with older versions of browsers are targets for this phishing attack.
Set the `rel` attribute to include the `noopener` value, thus disallowing the linked page to access the original page through the `window.opener` object.

issues.extra: reverse_tabnabbing_html -- app/views/login.html -- ##Σ-markup - html - body - div - nav - div - ul - li - ul - li - p - a

events.description: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to. Secret type: `Password (generic)`.
Avoid setting sensitive configuration values as string literals. Instead, these values should be set using variables with the sensitive data loaded from an encrypted file or a secret store.

properties.longDescription: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

events.description: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to. Secret type: `Password (generic)`.
Avoid setting sensitive configuration values as string literals. Instead, these values should be set using variables with the sensitive data loaded from an encrypted file or a secret store.

properties.longDescription: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

events.description: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to. Secret type: `Password (generic)`.
Avoid setting sensitive configuration values as string literals. Instead, these values should be set using variables with the sensitive data loaded from an encrypted file or a secret store.

properties.longDescription: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

events.description: The `cookie.sameSite` option is either undefined or set to the insecure value `none` or `false`. In all three cases, the cookie's `SameSite` attribute protections are disabled, allowing the browser to send cookies in cross-site requests. An attacker can abuse this missing protection to facilitate cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

Explicitly set the `cookie.sameSite` value to `true` or `strict` to omit cookies from all cross-origin requests. Optionally, the `cookie.sameSite` value may be set to `lax` to allow cookies in cross-site requests when the user is navigating to the cookie's origin, such as when following a link.

properties.longDescription: The `cookie.sameSite` option is either undefined or set to the insecure value `none` or `false`. In all three cases, the cookie's `SameSite` attribute protections are disabled, allowing the browser to send cookies in cross-site requests. An attacker can abuse this missing protection to facilitate cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.
properties.type: Missing or insecure samesite attribute for session cookie

events.description: The configuration of the `client-sessions`, `cookie-session` or `express-session` library does not set the `secure` attribute of the session cookie. While web browsers send cookies with the `secure` attribute only over HTTPS, they do send cookies without it over HTTP. If an attacker can fool the victim's browser into sending an HTTP request to the vulnerable site (for example, with JavaScript code on a malicious page or with a phishing link), the victim's browser will send the vulnerable cookie in clear text. If the attacker can also intercept this network traffic, then they can steal the victim's session cookie and impersonate the victim.
Set the `secure` property to `true` explicitly to prevent the cookies from being sent over an insecure channel.

properties.longDescription: The configuration of the `client-sessions`, `cookie-session` or `express-session` library does not set the `secure` attribute of the session cookie. While web browsers send cookies with the `secure` attribute only over HTTPS, they do send cookies without it over HTTP. If an attacker can fool the victim's browser into sending an HTTP request to the vulnerable site (for example, with JavaScript code on a malicious page or with a phishing link), the victim's browser will send the vulnerable cookie in clear text. If the attacker can also intercept this network traffic, then they can steal the victim's session cookie and impersonate the victim.
properties.type: Secure attribute not set for session cookie

events.description: The `client-sessions`, `cookie-session` or `express-session` library sets the `path` attribute on the session cookie to the root or doesn't set `path` attribute (default value is root). If the application is hosted beneath a subdirectory and the cookie is copied to the root, then applications in other subdirectories will have access to this cookie. If any of these applications become compromised, the cookie of the victim site can be stolen from this application.
Set the `path` property to the subdirectory where the application is hosted, not the root directory, to prevent the cookie from being accessed from unauthorized paths.

properties.longDescription: The `client-sessions`, `cookie-session` or `express-session` library sets the `path` attribute on the session cookie to the root or doesn't set `path` attribute (default value is root). If the application is hosted beneath a subdirectory and the cookie is copied to the root, then applications in other subdirectories will have access to this cookie. If any of these applications become compromised, the cookie of the victim site can be stolen from this application.

events.description: The session storage that the `express-session` module provides explicitly or by default is insecure. This type of memory storage leaks memory under most conditions. An attacker may create numerous active sessions and cause a Denial-of-Service situation.

Set the `store` property to a third-party secure storage, such as MongoDB or Redis for a production environment. Use `connect-mongo` or `connect-redis` libraries accordingly to configure the session storage.

properties.longDescription: The session storage that the `express-session` module provides explicitly or by default is insecure. This type of memory storage leaks memory under most conditions. An attacker may create numerous active sessions and cause a Denial-of-Service situation.

events.description: HTTP responses contain an `X-Powered-By` header that reveals information about the server which helps attackers exploit known vulnerabilities or craft more targeted exploits.

Use `app.disable('x-powered-by')` to disable the `X-Powered-By` header. If you're using an older version of Express that does not support this setting and you can't upgrade, create a middleware to call `res.removeHeader("x-powered-by")` where `res` is the response object.

properties.longDescription: HTTP responses contain an `X-Powered-By` header that reveals information about the server which helps attackers exploit known vulnerabilities or craft more targeted exploits.

events.description: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to. Secret type: `Password (generic)`.
Avoid setting sensitive configuration values as string literals. Instead, these values should be set using variables with the sensitive data loaded from an encrypted file or a secret store.

properties.longDescription: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

events.description: A web server is created using the insecure `HTTP` scheme. As a result, application data is transmitted over an insecure channel where it can be read and modified by attackers.

Use the `https` library instead of the `http` library, or use the `createServer` method of the `http-server` library with the `https` option set to `true` to avoid sending data over the network in cleartext.

properties.longDescription: A web server is created using the insecure `HTTP` scheme. As a result, application data is transmitted over an insecure channel where it can be read and modified by attackers.

events.description: Setting the `autoescape` attribute to `false` disables the escaping mechanism of the Swig template engine. This may lead to XSS attack if untrusted data is not properly validated and escaped.
Set the `autoescape` attribute to `true`, or omit it as the default value is `true`.

properties.longDescription: Setting the `autoescape` attribute to `false` disables the escaping mechanism of the Swig template engine. This may lead to XSS attack if untrusted data is not properly validated and escaped.

Note that most contemporary browsers add the `noopener` value to the `rel` automatically by default. Thus, only users with older versions of browsers are targets for this phishing attack.

events.description: The `sandbox` attribute of an `iframe` is not set in HTML. This iframe loads content from a third-party site. If the JavaScript in that iframe is malicious or was compromised, an attacker can break out of the iframe, access the DOM of the main page, and mount a clickjacking or a phishing attack.

Enable all restrictions by setting the `sandbox` attribute of the `iframe` to an empty value, or just allow necessary capabilities by setting the `sandbox` attribute with specific value(`allow-forms`, `allow-modals`, `allow-scripts`, etc.). Avoid setting both `allow-scripts` and `allow-same-origin` at the same time as they are a vulnerable attributes combination.

events.description: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to. Secret type: `API key (generic)`.
Avoid setting sensitive configuration values as string literals. Instead, these values should be set using variables with the sensitive data loaded from an encrypted file or a secret store.

events.description: The application uses an unsafe evaluation method. If attacker-controlled code reaches this method, it may lead to remote code execution, code injection, or a cross-site scripting vulnerability.

Whenever possible, rewrite the application without using code evaluation functions. If the application absolutely needs to use dynamic code evaluation, send hard-coded strings, or user input after the input validation to these functions. If conditional execution is needed, map user input to hardcoded values and send them to the evaluation functions.

events.description: req.query is a source of tainted data

User-controlled input is used to specify an address that is used as a URL redirect or forward. An attacker can create a link to the trusted site that redirects to a malicious web site. This could enable the attacker to steal user credentials. An attacker can mount a phishing attack by modifying the URL value to point to a malicious Web site.
Validate whether the url being redirected or forwarded is present in the set of known safe URLs or redirects to a webpage from the same domain.

properties.longDescription: User-controlled input is used to specify an address that is used as a URL redirect or forward. An attacker can create a link to the trusted site that redirects to a malicious web site. This could enable the attacker to steal user credentials. An attacker can mount a phishing attack by modifying the URL value to point to a malicious Web site.
